posts.cooked:
We are using the WCP GrayT 2 stage elevator. This is our code for the elevator subsystem: 2025Bot/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/ElevatorSubsystem.java at master · Maeser8885/2025Bot · GitHub

I was wondering how to find the setpoints needed for it to work, since setpoints are usually in angles.

You can get a conversion factor by running the elevator up a few inches (say 20-30), measure how many inches it is from its start point, and divide that number by the number of rotations the motor reports.

From there, you can multiply the encoder’s current rotation value by that factor to get inches, and divide the setpoint in inches by that factor to get rotations.

With a 2 stage elevator, the simple math for your conversion factor should be:

2(gear_ratio*(pi*sprocket_pitch_diameter))

So if you are using a 5:1 gear box with a 24T sprocket (1.92in), this becomes:

2*((3.141593*1.92)/5) = 2.4127
And does my code work. This is my first time writing code for an elevator, so i just wanna make sure

Looks good. Only things I would change would be to move the target variable into a parameter in your setpoint method, and also make a command for that setpoint method.

I would also make commands to run the motor forwards and backwards at a low speed, e.g. 0.4.

We’re doing a similar thing using centimeters instead, but I ended using the motor shaft diameter times pi to get the circumference and am using that as my distance conversion. We haven’t been able to test that yet, but we will later today
You also have to account for gear ratio and sprocket size.
Also, with it, when I set the setpoint, will the grabber move after the elevator, or at the same time(its in robotcontainer)

I assume you’re talking about these:

Since setTargetCommand returns a Command , you don’t want to run it like a subroutine; you instead want to bind these two together as a composition e.g.:

This will run the two at the same time. If you want the grabber to move after the elevator, change alongWith to andThen .
